snippet: The attack on the web’s infrastructure laid bare new vulnerabilities linked to our reliance on cameras, smart thermostats and the rest of the internet of things....
abstract: Internet slowdown that swept East Coast points to high vulnerability inherent in increasing number of objects equipped with cameras and internet ability, known as 'internet of things'; malicious software infiltrated hundreds of thousands of such devices and commanded them to bombard Dyn DNS, Manchester, NH, company that acts as giant internet switchboard, with messages to overload its circuits; lack of consolidated cybersecurity in United States makes such attacks inevitable.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH
byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco.

lead_paragraph: The attack on the web’s infrastructure laid bare new vulnerabilities linked to our reliance on cameras, smart thermostats and the rest of the internet of things.

headline.main: A New Era of Internet Attacks Powered by Everyday Devices
headline.print_headline: When Crib Monitors Double as Web Weaponry
